posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
Here is a topic with absolutely no controversy whatsover attached to it .

So I wanted to do a brief summary (as I currently understand it) of the SparkPIDController. I’m doing this mostly as a check and also to see if there are things I’ve overlooked.

*For reference:  * The Feed Forward equations: v = velocity, a = acceleration

V =  ks * Math.signum(v) + kv * v + ka * a : for simple V =  kg + ks * Math.signum(v) + kv * v + ka * a : for elevator V =  kg * Math.cos(currentAngle) + ks * Math.signum(v) + kv * v + ka * a : for arm

The SparkPIDController supports setting kp, kv, ka values for position and velocity, (and some others but I’m going to ignore those for now).  You do this by using slots, which is a very common practice.  You set the reference (setpoint/goal/etc.) to the desired value and it should handle the rest given proper tuning.  It runs its control loops in 1 ms increments by default (I think?).

You can also add an arbitrary feedforward in either volts or output percent.

It runs its control loop in 1 ms increments by default.  (I think?)

For Simple Velocity Controlled Mechanisms: There is no way to handle ks * Math.signum(v) as far as I know on the controller level.  This would have to be done on the RIO at either its default frequency (20ms) or another through addPeriodic or NotifierCommand.  Then send the calculated voltage to the .setVoltage() method.

For Simple Position Controlled Mechanisms: Same issues as above but unfortunately we don’t have a controller level profiler (Smart Motion doesn’t count).  So any motion profiling would have to be done on the RIO.

For Elevator Mechanism: A brief ray of sunshine. You can add kg as an arbitraryFF, but all of the same issues as above apply.

For Arm Mechanism: Same issues as Simple Position and Velocity Mechanism and no support for angular torque kg * Math.cos(currentAngle)

So if I had a wishlist for improvements to REV’s hardware controlled PIDController all of the above would be my answer.

CTRE ’s TalonFX controller does have support for all of these but the implementation is before the scenes.  Though I would assume that most of the above equations are handled to the best of the controller’s ability.

However I might be mistaken on a few of these items.  Please let me know if I am.  We all grow together.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
narmstro:

For Elevator Mechanism: A brief ray of sunshine. You can add kg as an arbitraryFF, but all of the same issues as above apply.

For Arm Mechanism: Same issues as Simple Position and Velocity Mechanism and no support for angular torque kg * Math.cos(currentAngle)

The SparkMAX PID controller works well in many situations, but we generally avoid using it when a calculated feedforward term is required. In theory, you could calculate the feedforward term on the roboRIO, divide by the setpoint to get the gain, and then call setFF , but the documentation for the latter says “This uses the Set Parameter API and should be used infrequently.” (See also Closed Loop Control .)

There are now good examples of using more sophisticated state-space control , which I don’t see getting implemented in motor controller firmware anytime soon.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: Thank you for sharing the links.  I knew of these.  I just wanted more perspective, just to make sure I didn’t miss anything.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
This is where I might call on wisdom from the sages.

I suppose that if you did not do any feedforward you could use an I term.  If I understand things correctly  you probably don’t need a kI term just kP and kD if you are using a feedforward.  I believe doing this makes things less accurate, but the spark max support it.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
The Spark MAX controller implements a less powerful model than you can implement on the roboRIO, but can run more frequently and with less lag.  Those are powerful advantages that can compensate for the simpler model in many usage scenarios.

I bring up the state space controllers because (as I understand it) they have two major advantages: They can (optionally) be initialized from physical properties (e.g. mass, moment of interia, gear ratio) instead of developing constants empirically; and they can adapt their behaviour on-the-fly.   (In theory, one could build a calculator to initialize SparkMAX parameters from a physical model, but I’m not aware of one.)

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
bovlb:

(In theory, one could build a calculator to initialize SparkMAX parameters from a physical model, but I’m not aware of one.)

That’s effectively sysId

bovlb:

The Spark MAX controller implements a less powerful model than you can implement on the roboRIO, but can run more frequently and with less lag. Those are powerful advantages that can compensate for the simpler model in many usage scenarios.

I agree.  Running a simple flywheel, wheel, turret, elevator wouldn’t have any serious concerns.  You couldn’t handle static friction as you do with ks, unless I’m missing something.

posts.name: Will Toth
posts.cooked:
Ignoring any profiled control modes here. Feed forward is based on the setpoint not the measured value, otherwise it would be called feedback. You can only update the setpoint as fast as your code runs on the rio, so there is no need to run in on the Spark itself. The arbFF gives you everything you need to do any feed forward you could want. WPILib gives you all the helper classes you need. As an added bonus both of these already use voltage. The FRC docs include an example of all of this already.

Implementing this on the controller would be far less flexible than on the rio, and it doesn’t change the amount code by much, if at all.

It would be helpful if there was a feed forward specific example. I also believe the kFD parameter should be deprecated and ‘arbFF’ given a better name. That may also

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
Ah I completely forgot about the kFF value.  And the lack of a kA.

Will_Toth:

You can only update the setpoint as fast as your code runs on the rio, so there is no need to run in on the Spark itself.

Sure but CTRE does it on the TalonFX

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: You can specify an arbitrary feed forward and pass it on from your WPILib feed forward class into the Spark set method.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: You can, but at the RIO’s freq and no real support for ka, cosine, and ks

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: You’re quite right, of course.  You can use setReference to set an arbitrary feedforward term.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
Support for kS, kA, cosine etc is in WPILib.

The only sin I see that REV has committed is make “Smart Motion” only close loop on velocity, rather than position.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
True.  I think my quibbles with REV is that here you have the TalonFX from CTRE that has all of the feedback/forward support and its just calls to the motor controllers through their setControl request implementation and here you have REV where you’re doing things on the RIO at 20 ms frame rates unless you use addPeriodic or Notifier Commands.  Though maybe my need for higher framerates is unnecessary except for odometry.

And who knows maybe CTRE has problems with their feedback/forward setup that I’m unaware of.

This section here has me concerned as its incorrect for the ks parameter in position control.

EDIT:  I had a brain fart here. I had to reread it to fix.  This is actually fine for the ks

Closed-loop control typically refers to control of a motor that relies on sensor data to adjust based on error. Systems/mechanisms that rely on maintaining a certain position or velocity achieve th...

posts.name: Will Toth
posts.cooked:
The frequency is illrelevant here. Feed forward is only based on setpoint. For example, the simple motor feed forward in WPILib is

ff = kS + kV * desired_velocity + kA * desired_acceleration

You can only updated the desired values as fast as you update the desired values. The controller can’t guess what that is.

Now, in the case of a profiled mode, that is totally different, since the setpoint is calculated by the controller. In that case it makes sense for the controller to explicitly support these modes. In that case yes, the SPARK does not support this, but the TalonFX does. The spark doesn’t have a good profiled mode because of this.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: Feedforward does depend on frame rates for a more accurate discretized model.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: When you’re characterizing, possibly. But when you’re controlling the mechanism 50Hz is fine, since the feedforward is based on the setpoint, and you’re not changing your setpoint that often. Of course, as Toth has said, if the motor controller is executing a motion profile, then it needs to do the feed forward calculations on its own, since the setpoint is constantly changing over the course of a motion.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
This isn’t true in general. Consider a DC motor we’re trying to make follow a reference trajectory.

SimpleMotorFeedforward.calculate(velocity, acceleration) assumes the acceleration is constant between timesteps, which isn’t true for the real system (it exponentially decays in practice). The error introduced by this decreases with smaller dt. Here’s the feedforward equation:

u_k = k_s sgn(x_k) + k_v r_k + k_a dr_k/dt

where r_k is the velocity reference.

SimpleMotorFeedforward.calculate(currentVelocity, nextVelocity, dt) gives the exact voltage to move between the two velocities in the given time, so you can have exact feedforward tracking regardless of the value of dt. Here’s the feedforward equation:

u_k = k_s sgn(r_k) + B_d^+(r_{k+1} - A_d r_k) where A_d = eᴬᵀ \\
B_d = A^{-1}(e^{AT} - I)B \\
A = -\frac{k_v}{k_a} \\
B = \frac{1}{k_a} \\
T = \text{time delta}

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
Fair point.  I should know better .

I think I got my wires crossed on this one.

You can still make the argument though that using dt makes for a more accurate setup.
